abstracts.cdata!:
The Poor Rural Communities Development
            Project seeks to improve livelihood security, and achieve a
            sustained participation of the rural poor in project design,
            implementation, and in the monitoring and evaluation aspects
            within the three project provinces. The project entails six
            components: 1) Sustainable mountain agriculture - will
            support agricultural development, and sustainable
            livelihoods in villages where communities live in remote
            mountainous environments. The design and implementation of
            the component is based on the two principles of targeting
            and reaching poor households, and achieving environmental
            sustainability. The following activities are included:
            improving household agricultural productivity and
            diversification; developing farmer-to-farmer services; and,
            agricultural training and technical support services. 2)
            Basic rural infrastructure - includes construction and
            improvement of roads, tracks and paths; provision of potable
            water supplies for humans and livestock; construction of
            small water conservancy works (including irrigation and
            drainage) with associated land improvements; extension of
            rural electrification and communications networks; and,
            household energy and sanitation improvements. 3) Basic
            education - will address the challenges of a limited access
            to primary education by poor and vulnerable children,
            particularly girls and disabled children, of ineffective
            adult training and education for rural community
            development, of inadequate skills and capabilities of
            teachers for both schooling, and adult education, and, of
            the high burden of education expenses on poor families, in
            addition to the burden of poor infrastructure. To this end,
            the component comprises a nine-year compulsory pilot
            education program in selected project villages, seeking to
            integrate schools and communities through the transformation
            of schools into community learning centers. Innovative
            teaching methodologies will be provided to teachers, and,
            training services to adults will be provided in project
            villages, with a focus on functional literacy education. 4)
            Basic health - will provide financial assistance for medical
            care to the poor, ensuring basic health services, which will
            include free maternal care and immunization, and, support
            for inpatient care expenses; health education for
            communities on basic health, and HIV/AIDS will be also
            supported, and, training assistance will be provided. 5)
            Community capacity building - will strengthen grassroots
            capacity in community development management, and includes
            activities to improve basic production and skills within
            poor farm households; strengthen community leaders'
            basic skills on local administrative management, basic
            financial management, development of village-level planning,
            local dispute resolution, and small-scale infrastructure
            construction, including special training for women. 6)
            Project management and monitoring - will support and
            facilitate the timely provision of counterpart funding,
            smooth coordination among government line agencies, and,
            prod an effective project supervision, and monitoring and evaluation.
